docs.lead_paragraph: Because Manny Ramírez’s relationship with the Red Sox ended with some lingering questions about his behavior, Commissioner Bud Selig asked Rob Manfred, one of baseball’s executive vice presidents, to conduct interviews on the topic. Selig and Manfred declined comment Friday, but baseball officials said Manfred’s exploration had ended and would not lead to any disciplining.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was only April, but the Boston Red Sox were in trouble. Despite glowing preseason predictions, they started the season with six consecutive losses, and by April 15 their record was a dismal 2-10. Their vaunted lineup was hitting .224, and the pitching staff was allowing 6.6 runs a game. Alarms sounded throughout New England. In the ensuing hysteria it was learned that no American League team had ever overcome so shaky a start to qualify for the playoffs, let alone make a serious bid at the World Series. Surely such an omen meant the 2011 Red Sox were doomed.
docs.abstract: Keeping Score column on how Boston Red Sox overcame a dismal 2-10 start to emerge in June as the most dominant team in the the major leagues. (M)

headline.main: Doomed in April, a Juggernaut in June

docs.lead_paragraph: Boston Red Sox pitcher Josh Beckett was cleared for physical activity but will miss his scheduled spring training start Thursday because of concussion symptoms. He was hit on the left temple while shagging balls in the outfield Monday. The Red Sox said they expected Beckett to take his next turn, but the decision will be made after input from the pitching coach Curt Young. (AP) MARLINS' JOHNSON STRUGGLES Josh Johnson, who missed the final month of last season because of back and shoulder problems, struggled through his first spring training start as the Florida Marlins lost to the Washington Nationals, 8-4. Johnson pitched one and two-thirds innings, giving up five runs and four hits. Washington's Roger Bernadina hit a three-run homer off Johnson. (AP)
docs.abstract: Bats blog on Boston Red Sox starting pitcher Josh Beckett recovering from concussion; other MLB news noted. (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a saga worthy of a grand title, something like ''Around the Red Sox in 80 Days.'' It has been that long since Theo Epstein sneaked out of Fenway Park in a gorilla suit on Halloween, the day his contract expired, leaving the Red Sox without their popular general manager. The events that followed have been shrouded in mystery, every move or nonmove cast against Epstein's departure. Would the Red Sox still have lost Johnny Damon to the Yankees if Epstein had stayed? Would they still have traded for Josh Beckett and would Manny Ramirez have been gone? Would Edgar Renteria, Epstein's handpicked shortstop, still have been shipped to Atlanta?
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox officially welcome back general manager Theo Epstein, who left team more than two months ago, but kept in contact with front office (M)2
docs.snippet: The Red Sox on Thursday officially welcomed back their former general manager, Theo Epstein, in a full-time baseball operations role....

headline.main: Red Sox Return Epstein To the Full-Time Lineup

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost two months after defying the Curse of the Bambino and only one day after saying goodbye to Pedro Martínez, the Boston Red Sox kept moving on yesterday by welcoming the living embodiment of Babe Ruth himself -- the rambunctious former Yankee David Wells. Wells passed a physical and was introduced at a Fenway Park news conference, and the timing could not have been more striking. It came hours after Curt Schilling told a Boston radio station that the healing for his surgically repaired right ankle was behind schedule, and that he may not be ready to pitch opening day.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox introduce pitcher David Wells, who was signed to two-year contract; photos (M)7

headline.main: In Boston, Good News and Bad News

docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the death of a Red Sox fan hit by a police pepper-spray weapon after the team's playoff victory, Boston officials are imposing restrictions on the bars around Fenway Park and are considering discontinuing use of the pepper-spray gun. The Red Sox' historic victory over the Yankees Wednesday night sent as many as 80,000 people streaming out of bars and homes into the streets around Fenway Park after midnight, many of whom climbed on cars and lampposts and swung from trees.
docs.snippet: Boston officials are imposing restrictions on the bars around Fenway Park to curb violence during the World Series....

headline.main: Death of a Red Sox Fan Leads to Stricter Rules

byline.original: By PAM BELLUCK and KATIE ZEZIMA

docs.lead_paragraph: David Ortiz's toothy, broad smile dominates the imposing billboard just outside the main gates of Fenway Park, imploring Red Sox fans to hang in there. ''Keep the Faith,'' says the billboard, perhaps suggesting that with a player like Ortiz, anything is possible, even in a city that has not won a World Series since 1918. In this instance, no one can accuse the Red Sox of false advertising. Ortiz blossomed when he joined the Red Sox last season as a free agent, puncturing the Yankees in head-to-head games and posting overall numbers -- .288 batting average, 31 home runs and 101 runs batted in -- that led to a fifth-place finish in the American League's most valuable player voting.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox player David Ortiz has 19 home runs and .304 batting average and leads American League in RBI; photos (M)
